unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about military titles. My grandfather, Subedar Major (Retd.) Rajinder Singh, always held himself with such dignity. Even years after leaving the Indian Army, you could see the discipline ingrained in him. He'd tell stories, usually after a few pegs of Old Monk, about his time in the '71 war.
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about military titles. My grandfather, Subedar Major, Retired, Rajinder Singh, always held himself with such dignity. Even years after leaving the Indian Army, you could see the discipline ingrained in him. He'd tell stories, usually after a few pegs of Old Monk, about his time in the seventy one war.

unnormalised: He started as a Sepoy, fresh out of Punjab. Training was tough, he said, but he rose through the ranks - Lance Naik, then Naik, Havildar. Each promotion meant more responsibility, more respect from the jawans under his command. He spoke of his commanding officers - Brig. Sharma and Col. Verma – with genuine admiration, remembering their leadership during critical operations. The chain of command, he'd explain, was everything. You followed orders from your superior officers, no questions asked, and took responsibility for your men.

unnormalised: Getting to Subedar Major, he said, was a culmination of years of dedication. It wasn’t just about seniority; it was about proving himself as a leader, a mentor, and a warrior. He'd earned every stripe, every medal. He often remarked how different things were in the Air Force and the Navy. He'd casually mention ranks like Wing Commander or Admiral, but his heart was always with the men on the ground.

unnormalised: He passed away a few years ago, but the stories, the values he instilled in us, those remain. He taught me respect for all ranks, from the highest General to the youngest recruit. And he showed me that true leadership isn’t just about giving orders; it's about inspiring trust and taking care of your people, even after you're Subedar Major (Retd.).
